posts.name: Falon Clark
posts.cooked:
Hello! My team is discussing whether we want to buy new swerve modules for next year, and I’d like some info on how often teams replace their competition modules.

We currently have two sets of Mk4i modules, with 2 seasons of use (about 80 matches) and 1 season of use (about 50 matches).

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked:
We have not once had to replace a module. They either stay on an old bot or transfer from bot to bot. The only thing we swap out over time is the tread and we take them apart to clean them each season. I have no experience with the SDS swerve but I imagine the only thing you might need to replace over time would be the belt. (or the gears if they’re showing very noticeable wear but my team has never experienced that).

However, there is nothing wrong with getting a shiny new set if you want to upgrade to a newer or different version, switch manufacturers, or have an extra chassis to use. The MK5 is coming out next season and it is very cool so it could be good for your next set.

posts.name: Falon Clark
posts.cooked: When I say swap out I more meant buying new ones, mb. I do want to buy new ones, but there is an argument to be made that the packaging benefits, and ability to use molded plastic wheels without buying from vexpro, is not worth $1200 for X2 modules, or the MK5 whenever it comes out.

posts.name: Marcus
posts.cooked: In my opinion, modules are reusable so long as you take good care of them. This includes adequately lubricating the gears, keeping the gears free from debris, and proper initial assembly. Of course, best perfromance can be had from new modules, however a lower resource team could benefit more from upgrading the drive motors if they are not the top-tier kraken x60s or purchasing grippier wheels. Our team always shims the gears when assembling to reduce the amount of wiggle and hence potential wear induced upon the module components. One of the most prevalent signs of worn modules are increased backlash on both drive and steer axis.

posts.name: 51 Drive Coach
posts.cooked: We upgraded to 4is this year. However we still used alot of components over and over again. We used the mk4s for 3 seasons, and used them as base to upgrade this year. we just took them apart, cleaned them up real good and reassembled over the last few years. They have been bulletproof for us.

posts.name: AllenGregoryIV
posts.cooked:
We have used Mk4i’s since 2022 and I would be happy to reuse nearly all of the modules we own. This year we did reuse modules and just refurbished them before they went on our competition robot. We replaced several of the small bearings which are cheap, we replaced the belts and wheels. We also bought brand new mid and bottom plates because we wanted the 10-32 holes and threads. For the main bearing, shafts, and gears we reused them after cleaning and inspecting them. I think we replaced a few things like the shoulder bolts axles, 1 or 2 steering shafts where the aluminum teeth didn’t look perfect, etc.

Overall it was much cheaper to reuse.

Upgrading your modules won’t be the thing that makes your robot win more matches directly, so if your resources could better go to improving your robot/team in other ways it may make sense to do that.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked: My $0.02: Refurbish the modules you have (per Allen’s post) and buy a single complete spare to have in the pits in case of a catastrophic issue.
